description.narrative:
SAFAIDS har ansökt om 75 miljoner kronor för att genomföra sin regionala strategi “Transforming the Policy Environment for Accelerating Access to Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) by adolescents and young people, within an SDGs framework, in southern Africa 2018 – 2020.”
Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att bidra till en mer gynnsam politisk miljö som möjliggör positiva SRHR-resultat bland ungdomar och unga kvinnor i södra Afrika senast 2020. Det föreslagna programmet har fyra strategiska mål.
- Policyutveckling: Stödja utvecklingen av SADC-riktlinjer gällande ungdomar och sexuellt och könsbaserat våld senast 2020,
- Policypåverkan: Påverka SADCs medlemsstater att öka insatserna mot oavsiktliga graviditeter och osäkra aborter bland sexuellt aktiva ungdomar senast 2020,
- Övervakning av socialt ansvar: Stärka kapaciteten hos regionala ungdomsorganisationer och nätverk för ansvarsutkrävande vad gäller tillhandahållandet av SRHR Information och tjänster riktade till ungdomar i södra Afrika senast 2020,
- Evidens och kunskapsutbyte: Förbättra utbytet av modeller, innovationer och strategier för sexuellt och/eller könsbaserad våld (SGBV), oavsiktlig graviditet och osäker abort bland ungdomar senast 2020.
SAfAIDS har varit partner till det regionala SRHR-teamet sedan 2004. SAfAIDs tar emot finansiering från en diversifierad pool av finansiärer som inkluderar Sveriges regionala SRHR-team, HIVOS, Irland, EU, UNAIDS Regional support team och Stop AIDS Now. Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att finansieras fullt ut av Sida.

SAfAIDS has applied for 75 million SEK to implement their regional strategy programme, Transforming the Policy Environment for Accelerating Access to Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) by adolescents and young people, within an SDGs framework, in southern Africa 2018 – 2020.
The overall goal of the intervention is to contribute towards a more conducive policy environment that enables positive SRHR outcomes among adolescents and young women, in Southern Africa, by 2020. The proposed programme will realise 4 strategic objectives;
- Policy Development: Support the development of Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) Sexual Gender-based Violence (SGBV) Response Guidelines for Adolescents by Member States, by 2020,
- Policy Advocacy: Advocate to SADC Member States to scale up prevention of unintended pregnancies and unsafe abortions among sexually active adolescents by 2020,
- Social Accountability Monitoring: Strengthen the capacity of regional youth organisations and networks in social accountability monitoring of the delivery of youth-friendly SRH Information and services in Southern Africa, by 2020,
- Evidence and Knowledge Sharing: Enhance knowledge sharing of models, innovations and strategies on Sexual Gender Based Violence (SGBV), unintended pregnancies and unsafe abortions among adolescents and social accountability monitoring within the region and across the broader sector by 2020.
SAfAIDS has presented a project proposal whose objectives are clear, and the intervention logic clearly thought out. The proposal has provided for a baseline survey to be conducted within the first two months of programme inception to ensure that the data can be utilized to strengthen programme components. A Baseline Protocol will be developed in the first month of the programme, defining the variables to be measured against each programme objective, methodologies and data definitions. The programme mid-term review and end line survey will be measured against the baseline. It is assessed that current results framework requires further input and SAfAIDS is expected to submit a revised version by 30 June 2018. This deliverable has been included as an agreement condition for the 2018 third grant disbursement.
In regards to the budget, it is assessed that the proposed total budget of 75,000,000 SEK for this invention is sufficient, and reasonable to meet the planned outcomes. The allocated budget for the SAfAIDS six months inception phase is USD1,958,836 (SEK16,249,131). Six per cent (6%) of the inception budget relates to activities for a technical expert report, internal regional 2 day inception meeting, regional partner visit and regional and national sensitization meetings with key stakeholders. 28% of the program activities also relate to costs for arranging a regional rapid assessment on the adolescent Sexual Gender Based Violence (SGBV) related policy environment, organizing a meeting to develop an Assessment Methodology Protocol (AMP), conducting an induction meeting for assessment team, conducting a national meeting to validate the rapid assessment findings, regional meeting to validate the rapid assessment findings, developing a mobile social accountability monitoring application (including tech tools and systems) for SRHR in partnership with Rhodes University, develop a toolkit on social accountability monitoring for youth SRH Services and Technical Consultancy. Two per cent (2%) of the budget has been allocated to monitoring & evaluation and finance compliance and monitoring visits, while six per cent (6%) of the budget has been allocated to capital expenditure. Ten per cent (10%) of the budget relates to administration costs whilst 48% of the planned budget relates to staff costs. The reason for the high staff costs is a result of SAfAIDS not complying with MCP/PLGHA, which has resulted in SAfAIDS losing USAID funding that was contributing to SAfAIDS staff and administration costs of up to 16%.
SAfAIDS receives funding from a diversified pool of funders that include Sweden, Hivos, Irish Aid, European Union, UNAIDS Regional, Stop AIDS Now, and USAID. The largest funders are Sweden and USAID who together contributed more than 60% of resources to SAfAIDS. The fact that SAFAIDS receives funds from USAID is subject of concern due to United States President Trump’s reinstatement of the 2001 Presidential Memorandum on the ‘Mexico City Policy’ (MCP)/PLGHA. U.S. President Trump further directed the Secretary of State to implement a plan to extend the MCP/PLGHA to global health assistance furnished by all U.S. departments or agencies (“Protecting Life in Global Health Health Assistance PGLHA). MCP/PLGHA has a significant impact on SAfAIDS work as it prohibits active promotion of abortion as a form of family planning; and prohibits advocating for the right to abortion or legal reform to make abortion legal, all of which are activities that the organization conducts. SAfAIDS Board took a decision on 17 August 2017 not to comply with MCP/PLGHA.Through taking this principled position of not signing the MCP/PLGHA, SAFAIDS ceased access to USAIDS funding for the DREAMS country programmes by 30th September 2017. SAfAIDS negotiated with USAID to transfer the whole Dreams program, staff, and budget (USD3,390,720) as well as vehicles and equipment to FHI360; the offer was welcomed by both USAID and the partner FHI360. Forty five (45) staff members from the DREAMS program Zimbabwe were moved by 30 September 2017. SAfAIDS managed DREAMS program in South Africa will also be closed and the USAID funds will move to another partner. The process of close out for South Africa office will begin 1 December 2017 and will be completed by end of February 2018. By not signing on MCP/PLGHA, SAfAIDS has lost 46% of their funding from USAID. However, with the DREAMS program now transferred to FHI, SAfAIDS will lose up to 16% of the USAID funding which was contributing towards staff and administration costs.
SAfAIDS as an organisation has undergone major organisational structural changes within a short period of time due to not complying with MCP/PLGHA. In the submitted proposal to Sweden’s Regional SRHR Team, a transition process has been factored in to allow SAfAIDS to position themselves strategically to the program, especially that SAfAIDS will be working more on a regional level with advocacy and policy change. The inception phase of the program will include restructuring of the organization. A program organogram will be developed to outline channels and links within the team and across countries. SAfAIDS will also engage a change management consultant to assist in this process. It is expected that this additional restructuring process is going to create new insecurity among the remaining staff, which will have an impact on staff morale, and may remove staff focus from the intervention, given the potential uncertainties that may accompany such changes. As a result, SAfAIDS may have challenges in retaining skilled staff within the organisation. In trying to mitigate this risk, SAfAIDS will engage staff, in an effort to sustain staff moral through clarity of roles, inclusion in operational decisions, staff team-building exercises, staff retreats and staff motivational events. SAfAIDS will also address the donor funding situation for SAfAIDS organisation as a whole and will continue to diversify its funding base to ensure financial sustainability. Sweden’s Regional SRHR Team will continue to monitor the transition process through dialogue with SAfAIDS, the transition process has also been included as part of the agreement conditions. The 3 year revised budget will be reflective of the organization structure changes within SAfAIDS. Despite the current financial gap created from the loss of the USAID funds, the entire proposed SAfAIDS intervention will be funded by Sweden; therefore program operations will not be financially affected.
